title: Right Ear Barotrauma and Tympanic Membrane Perforation
chief_complaint: I heard a popping sound and felt pain in my right ear while the plane was descending last week. Since then, my hearing has been muffled on that side and I have some ringing.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset one week ago during an airplane flight descent.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Otalgia (at onset), intermittent tinnitus, muffled hearing.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Perception of muffled hearing in the right ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Evaluation of hearing status following the flight incident.

history.present_illness: Patient flew last week; during descent, experienced a popping sound and otalgia in the right ear. Reports muffled hearing and intermittent tinnitus in the right ear since. No symptoms in the left ear.
history.otologic_history: No other reported otologic symptoms or history.
history.medical_psych_history: Family history of parents acquiring hearing loss later in life.
history.prior_management: None reported prior to this visit.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows mild conductive hearing loss rising to normal sensitivity, with air-bone gaps present from 250-2000 Hz. Left ear thresholds are within normal limits (0-10 dB HL).

numeric_results.RE_Configuration: Mild rising to slight conductive loss (250-2000 Hz), normal >3000 Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Reception Thresholds (SRT) are in agreement with Pure Tone Averages (PTA). Word Recognition Scores (WRS) are excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear tympanogram is flat (Type B) with a large ear canal volume, consistent with a perforation. Left ear tympanogram is normal (Type A).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a mild, low-frequency conductive hearing loss in the right ear and normal hearing sensitivity in the left ear. Speech recognition ability is excellent in both ears. Tympanometry reveals a flat tracing with an abnormally large ear canal volume in the right ear, consistent with a tympanic membrane perforation likely secondary to barotrauma.
counseling_points: The 'popping' sound and pain you felt on the plane likely caused a small hole (perforation) in your right eardrum.
The hearing test confirms a 'conductive' hearing loss, meaning sound isn't getting through the eardrum efficiently, but the inner ear nerve is healthy.
The large volume reading on the pressure test confirms the perforation is currently open.
It is very important to keep the ear dry (water precautions) to prevent infection while it heals.
We will monitor this closely; many small perforations heal on their own, but surgical repair is an option if it persists.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is generally healthy but annoyed by the muffled hearing and ringing since the flight.
You are not in acute severe pain now, but recall the pain on the plane vividly.
You have no history of ear infections as a child, making this event novel and slightly concerning.
